 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom align=right&gt;2.16&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom nowrap=nowrap&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom align=right&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom align=right&gt;2.21&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom nowrap=nowrap&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;/tr&gt;
 &lt;!-- End Table Body --&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 Options granted under the 2011 Plan that are subject to
 service-based vesting are generally subject to partial accelerated
 vesting upon certain terminations of employment of the
 optionholder. In the event of the termination of an
 optionholder&amp;#x2019;s employment due to death or disability or
 in
 the event of the termination of an optionholder&amp;#x2019;s employment
 by the Company without cause or by the optionholder for good reason
 after March&amp;#xA0;8
 2013
 that portion of the service-based stock
 options that would have become vested upon the next annual vesting
 date will vest as of the employment termination date.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 The fair value for service-based stock options granted was
 estimated at the date of grant using a Black-Scholes option pricing
 model with assumptions determined in the same manner as
 performance-based stock options described above. The following
 table presents the weighted-average assumptions for service-based
 stock options granted for the periods indicated:&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 16pt; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;
 &amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;table style=FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=84% align=center border=0&gt;&lt;!-- Begin Table Head --&gt;
 &lt;tr&gt;
 &lt;td width=94%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom width=1%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom width=1%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;!-- End Table Body --&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Rollover stock options&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 Certain options granted under the 2011 Plan were issued in exchange
 for options to purchase DMFC&amp;#x2019;s common stock granted under the
 Company&amp;#x2019;s previous equity plans (the &amp;#x201C;Rollover
 Options&amp;#x201D;). There was a total of 9
385
492 Rollover Options
 granted with a fair value of $3.75 per share. During fiscal 2014
 701
867 Rollover Options were cancelled and repurchased in
 connection with executive departures and 5
444
483 remain
 outstanding as of April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014. During fiscal 2013 and
 fiscal 2012
 573
015 and 2
666
127
 respectively
 Rollover Options
 were cancelled and repurchased in connection with executive
 departures. The Company did not incur any expense in connection
 with the issuance of the Rollover Options because they were granted
 in exchange for options of equal value. The Rollover Options are
 fully vested
 and generally remain subject to their original terms
 under the Company&amp;#x2019;s previous equity plans
 with applicable
 adjustments to convert the exercise price and number of shares of
 such options. Further
 Rollover Options do not count toward the
 shares of common stock available for grant under the 2011 Plan.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 1px; MARGIN-TOP: 16px&gt;
 &amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;

 indicated was as follows:&lt;/p&gt;

001&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;td valign=bottom align=right&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;/tr&gt;
 &lt;!-- End Table Body --&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 Options forfeited represent the number of unvested options that
 were forfeited in connection with the termination of employment of
 the optionholders. Options cancelled represent the number of vested
 options that were subject to repurchase and cancellation by the
 Company in connection with the termination of employment of the
 optionholders. The weighted-average exercise price is generally
 equivalent to the fair value of common stock per share.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 As of April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014
 there was approximately $14.6 million of
 unrecognized stock compensation cost
 which is expected to be
 recognized over a weighted-average period of 1.9 years. As of
 April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014
 the weighted-average remaining contractual
 life of options outstanding was 6.6 years.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Restricted common stock&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 During fiscal 2012
 Parent granted 1
366
199 shares of restricted
 common stock with a fair value and purchase price of $5.00 per
 share. The restricted shares generally vest over three years from
 the employee&amp;#x2019;s anniversary date of hire. During fiscal 2012
 Parent also granted 400
000 shares of restricted common stock with
 a fair value and purchase price of $5.00 per share which were
 immediately vested.&lt;/p&gt;


 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 14pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Recently Issued Accounting Standards&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 14pt&gt;
 In February 2013
 the Financial Accounting Standards Board
 (&amp;#x201C;FASB&amp;#x201D;) issued an Accounting Standards Update
 (&amp;#x201C;ASU&amp;#x201D;) related to comprehensive income. The amendments
 require an entity to provide information about the amounts
 reclassified out of accumulated other comprehensive income by
 component. This new accounting pronouncement is effective for
 fiscal years and interim periods within those years
 beginning
 after December&amp;#xA0;15
 2012
 with early adoption permitted.
 Accordingly
 the Company has included the enhanced disclosure in
 Note 12.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;
 In May 2014
 the FASB issued an ASU related to revenue from
 contracts with customers. The new standard provides a five-step
 approach to be applied to all contracts with customers. The ASU
 also requires expanded disclosures about revenue recognition. For
 the Company
 the ASU is effective for annual reporting periods
 beginning after December&amp;#xA0;15
 2016
 including interim periods.
 Early adoption is not permitted.&amp;#xA0;The Company is currently
 evaluating this guidance and the impact it will have on its
 consolidated financial statements.&lt;/p&gt;

 &lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 1px; MARGIN-TOP: 12px&gt;
 &amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;
 During the fiscal year ended April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014
 the
 Company&amp;#x2019;s goodwill and intangible assets increased by a total
 of $418.0 million
 with a $123.3 million increase for
 non-amortizable trademarks
 a $157.4 million increase for customer
 relationships
 and a $137.3 million increase for goodwill
 due to
 the Natural Balance acquisition (see Note 5).&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 Amortization expense for the periods indicated below was as follows
 (in millions):&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 12pt; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;
 &amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;table style=FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=84% align=center border=0&gt;
 &lt;tr&gt;
 &lt;td width=91%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom width=1%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom width=1%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom width=1%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom width=1%&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 14pt&gt;
 As of April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014
 the weighted-average life of the
 Company&amp;#x2019;s amortizable intangible assets was 19.3 years.&lt;/p&gt;


 &lt;p style=margin-top:16pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Stock Compensation Expense:&lt;/b&gt; The Company expenses employee
 stock option grants and other stock-based compensation over the
 vesting period
 based on the fair value on the date the stock-based
 compensation was granted. The Company recognizes stock compensation
 expense for performance-based stock options over the implied
 service periods when the Company believes it is probable that the
 performance targets
 as defined in the stock agreements
 will be
 achieved.&lt;/p&gt;


 &lt;table style=FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=100% border=0&gt;
 &lt;tr&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top width=8% align=left&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note&amp;#xA0;16.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top align=left&gt;&lt;b&gt;Segment and Geographic
 Information&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;/tr&gt;
 &lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 The Company has a single operating segment
 Pet Products
 which
 manufactures
 markets and sells branded and private label dry and
 wet pet food and pet snacks. The former Consumer Products segment
 is now reported as discontinued operations (see Note 4).&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 The Company&amp;#x2019;s chief operating decision-maker
 its CEO
 reviews financial information presented on a consolidated basis
 accompanied by disaggregated information on operating income for
 the operating segment for purposes of making decisions about
 assessing financial performance.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;

 &lt;td valign=top align=left&gt;As indicated in Note 1
 interest
 expense has not been allocated to discontinued operations.&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;

 percentage of total net sales:&lt;/p&gt;

 At April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014
 substantially all of the Company&amp;#x2019;s
 fixed assets are located in the United States.&lt;/p&gt;


 &lt;table style=FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; BORDER-COLLAPSE: collapse cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 width=100% border=0&gt;
 &lt;tr&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top width=8% align=left&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note&amp;#xA0;15.&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top align=left&gt;&lt;b&gt;Commitments and
 Contingencies&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;/tr&gt;
 &lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;!-- xbrl
body --&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 As part of its ongoing operations
 the Company enters into
 arrangements that obligate it to make future payments to various
 parties. Some of these contractual and other cash obligations are
 not reflected on the Consolidated Balance Sheets due to their
 nature. Such obligations include operating leases and other
 purchase commitments.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Lease Commitments&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 The Company leases certain property
 equipment and office and
 warehouse facilities. At April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014
 the aggregate minimum
 rental payments required under non-cancelable operating leases were
 as follows (in millions):&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 16pt; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 The Company sub-leases office space to the Acquiror of the Consumer
 Products Business in addition to others. Future minimum rentals to
 be received under all non-cancelable operating sub-leases through
 March&amp;#xA0;31
 2021 are $24.5 million as of April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Other Purchase Commitments&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Co-pack
 Packaging and Service Commitments.&lt;/i&gt; The Company has
 entered into non-cancelable agreements with co-packers
 packaging
 suppliers and other service providers with commitments generally
 ranging from one year to five years. In addition
 the Company has
 commitments under purchase orders with co-packers. Pricing under a
 metal can supplier agreement is adjusted up to twice a year to
 reflect changes in metal costs and annually to reflect changes in
 the costs of manufacturing.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;

 &lt;!-- End Table Body --&gt;&lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Ingredients and other.&lt;/i&gt; The Company has purchase commitments
 with vendors for various ingredients and other items. Total
 commitments under these agreements with payments due in fiscal 2015
 were approximately $138.5&amp;#xA0;million and with payments due in
 fiscal 2016 were approximately $8.9 million as of April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Union Contracts&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 As of April&amp;#xA0;27
 2014
 the Company had seven collective
 bargaining agreements with seven union locals covering
 approximately 45% of its hourly employees. Of these employees
 approximately 28% are covered under collective bargaining
 agreements scheduled to expire in fiscal 2015
 approximately 1% are
 covered under collective bargaining agreements scheduled to expire
 in fiscal 2016 to fiscal 2019 and approximately 71% are covered
 under collective bargaining agreements scheduled to expire in
 fiscal 2020. These agreements are subject to negotiation and
 renewal.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Legal Proceedings&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Commercial Litigation Involving the Company&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 On January&amp;#xA0;31
 2014
 Plaintiff filed a complaint in the
 Superior Court of California
 San Francisco County (&lt;i&gt;Gamez v. Del
 Monte)&lt;/i&gt; alleging violations of various California wage and hour
 statutes. This lawsuit was transferred to Del Monte Foods
 Inc.
 pursuant to the terms of the Purchase Agreement.&amp;#xA0;However
 liabilities associated with Kingsburg
 CA and Terminal Island
 CA
 were retained by the Company.&amp;#xA0;Del Monte Foods
 Inc. is
 maintaining primary defense of the litigation
 but any settlement
 made with the class will likely include the Company. The Company
 denies these allegations and intends to vigorously defend itself.
 The Company has accrued an estimated amount to resolve this matter
 that is not considered material.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 On April&amp;#xA0;19
 2013
 Plaintiff filed a complaint on behalf of
 himself and all other similarly situated employees in Superior
 Court of California
 Alameda County (&lt;i&gt;Montgomery v. Del
 Monte&lt;/i&gt;) alleging
 &lt;i&gt;inter alia&lt;/i&gt;
 failure to provide meal and
 rest periods and pay wages properly in violation of various
 California wage and hour statutes. This lawsuit was transferred to
 Del Monte Foods
 Inc. pursuant to the terms of the Purchase
 Agreement.&amp;#xA0;However
 liabilities associated with Kingsburg
 CA
 and Terminal Island
 CA were retained by the Company.&amp;#xA0;Del
 Monte Foods
 Inc. is maintaining primary defense of the litigation
 but any settlement made with the class will likely include the
 Company. The Company denies these allegations and intends to
 vigorously defend itself. Mediation was held on June&amp;#xA0;24
 2014.
 A tentative settlement
 pending court approval
 was reached. The
 Company has accrued an estimated amount to resolve this matter that
 is not considered material
 and the Company&amp;#x2019;s share of the
 settlement is expected to be covered by the amount accrued.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 On January&amp;#xA0;31
 2013
 a putative class action complaint was
 filed against the Company in the Circuit Court of Jackson County
 Missouri (&lt;i&gt;Harmon v. Del Monte&lt;/i&gt;) alleging that &lt;i&gt;Milo&amp;#x2019;s
 Kitchen&lt;/i&gt; chicken jerky treats (&amp;#x201C;Chicken Jerky
 Treats&amp;#x201D;) and &lt;i&gt;Milo&amp;#x2019;s Kitchen&lt;/i&gt; Chicken Grillers
 Recipe home-style dog treats contain &amp;#x201C;poisonous antibiotics
 and other potentially lethal substances.&amp;#x201D; Plaintiff seeks
 certification as a class action
 as well as restitution and damages
 not to exceed $75
000 per class member and the aggregated claim for
 damages of the class not to exceed $5.0 million under the Missouri
 Merchandising Practices Act. The complaint also alleges the Company
 continued to sell its Chicken Jerky Treats in Jackson County
 Missouri after it announced its recall of the product on
 January&amp;#xA0;9
 2013.&amp;#xA0;The Company successfully removed this
 case to federal court on March&amp;#xA0;12
 2013. On April&amp;#xA0;9
 2013
 Plaintiff filed a Second Amended Class Action Petition
 against the Company. The Company filed its Motion to Transfer to
 the Western District of Pennsylvania on April&amp;#xA0;19
 2013 and its
 Motion to Stay Pending the Motion to Transfer on April&amp;#xA0;25
 2013. The Motion to Stay was granted the same day it was filed. On
 May&amp;#xA0;6
 2013
 Plaintiff filed an Opposition to
 Defendant&amp;#x2019;s Motion to Transfer. The Company filed its Reply
 in Support of its Motion to Transfer on May&amp;#xA0;23
 2013. The
 Court denied the Company&amp;#x2019;s Motion to Transfer on
 July&amp;#xA0;22
 2013. The Company filed its Answer on August&amp;#xA0;13
 2013 and discovery has commenced. On February&amp;#xA0;3
 2014
 Plaintiff filed a Third Amended Complaint and filed a Fourth
 Amended Complaint to include an additional named plaintiff on
 April&amp;#xA0;22
 2014. On May&amp;#xA0;12
 2014
 Plaintiffs withdrew the
 original Motion for Class Certification and filed a new Motion for
 Class Certification on behalf of both plaintiffs. The Company
 denies these allegations and intends to vigorously defend itself.
 The Company cannot at this time reasonably estimate a range of
 exposure
 if any
 of the potential liability.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 1px; MARGIN-TOP: 16px&gt;
 &amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;
 On September&amp;#xA0;6
 2012
&amp;#xA0;October&amp;#xA0;12
 2012 and
 October&amp;#xA0;16
 2012
 three separate putative class action
 complaints were filed against the Company in U.S. District Court
 for the Northern District of California (&lt;i&gt;Langone v. Del
 Monte&lt;/i&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Ruff v. Del Monte&lt;/i&gt;
 and &lt;i&gt;Funke v. Del Monte&lt;/i&gt;
 respectively) alleging product liability claims relating to Chicken
 Jerky Treats. Specifically
 the complaints allege that
 Plaintiffs&amp;#x2019; dogs became ill as a result of consumption of
 Chicken Jerky Treats. The complaints also allege that the Company
 breached its warranties and California&amp;#x2019;s consumer protection
 laws. Each of the complaints seeks certification as a class action
 and damages in excess of $5.0 million. The Company denies these
 allegations and intends to vigorously defend itself. On
 December&amp;#xA0;18
 2012
 Plaintiffs filed a motion to relate and
 consolidate the &lt;i&gt;Langone&lt;/i&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Ruff&lt;/i&gt; and &lt;i&gt;Funke&lt;/i&gt;
 matters. The Company agreed that the cases are related but argued
 in its response that they should not be consolidated. The Court
 ordered the cases are related in an Order on January&amp;#xA0;24
 2013.
 In the &lt;i&gt;Langone&lt;/i&gt; case
 the Company filed a Motion to
 Transfer/Dismiss on February&amp;#xA0;1
 2013. Plaintiff in the
 &lt;i&gt;Langone&lt;/i&gt; matter voluntarily dismissed his Complaint without
 prejudice on February&amp;#xA0;21
 2013 and re-filed in the U.S.
 District Court for the Western District of Pennsylvania on
 May&amp;#xA0;21
 2013. The Company filed its Motion to Dismiss in the
 &lt;i&gt;Langone&lt;/i&gt; case with the U.S. District Court for the Western
 District of Pennsylvania on August&amp;#xA0;2
 2013. The individual
 claims in the &lt;i&gt;Langone&lt;/i&gt; case were settled for a de minimus
 amount
 and a stipulation to dismiss with prejudice was filed on
 November&amp;#xA0;25
 2013. On April&amp;#xA0;9
 2013
 the Court
 transferred &lt;i&gt;Ruff&lt;/i&gt; and &lt;i&gt;Funke&lt;/i&gt; to the U.S. District Court
 for the Western District of Pennsylvania but denied without
 prejudice Defendant&amp;#x2019;s motions to consolidate and dismiss. On
 April&amp;#xA0;23
 2013
 the Company filed its Motion to Dismiss in
 &lt;i&gt;Ruff&lt;/i&gt; and &lt;i&gt;Funke&lt;/i&gt; with the U.S. District Court for the
 Western District of Pennsylvania and its Reply in Support of its
 Motion to Dismiss in both cases on June&amp;#xA0;3
 2013. On
 February&amp;#xA0;11
 2014
 the Magistrate Judge issued a Report and
 Recommendation that the Motion to Dismiss be granted as to
 Plaintiffs&amp;#x2019; claim for unjust enrichment and denied in all
 other respects. The Company filed its objections to the Report and
 Recommendations on March&amp;#xA0;5
 2014. The District Judge adopted
 the Magistrate Judge&amp;#x2019;s Report and Recommendation on
 March&amp;#xA0;25
 2014. The Company filed its Answer on April&amp;#xA0;8
 2014. The Company cannot at this time reasonably estimate a range
 of exposure
 if any
 of the potential liability.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 On July&amp;#xA0;19
 2012
 a putative class action complaint was filed
 against the Company in U.S. District Court for the Western District
 of Pennsylvania (&lt;i&gt;Mazur v. Del Monte&lt;/i&gt;) alleging product
 liability claims relating to Chicken Jerky Treats. Specifically
 the complaint alleges that Plaintiff&amp;#x2019;s dog became ill and had
 to be euthanized as a result of consumption of Chicken Jerky
 Treats. The complaint also alleges that the Company breached its
 warranties and Pennsylvania&amp;#x2019;s consumer protection laws. The
 complaint seeks certification as a class action and damages in
 excess of $5.0 million. The Company denies these allegations and
 intends to vigorously defend itself. On August&amp;#xA0;3
 2012
 Plaintiff&amp;#x2019;s counsel filed a Motion to Consolidate the
 previously filed two similar class actions against Nestle Purina
 Petcare Company
 owner of the Waggin&amp;#x2019; Train brand of chicken
 jerky treats
 in U.S. District Court for the Northern District of
 Illinois under the federal rules for multi-district litigation
 (&amp;#x201C;MDL&amp;#x201D;). Plaintiff&amp;#x2019;s Motion also sought to
 include the case against the Company in the proposed MDL
 consolidation as a &amp;#x201C;related case.&amp;#x201D; On
 September&amp;#xA0;28
 2012
 the Court denied the MDL Motion. The case
 will now proceed in the jurisdiction in which it was originally
 filed. Plaintiff filed a Motion for Leave to Commence Limited
 Discovery on the subject of the voluntary recall of Chicken Jerky
 Treats on January&amp;#xA0;25
 2013. The Company filed its response
 opposing the Motion on February&amp;#xA0;8
 2013. The Court denied
 Plaintiff&amp;#x2019;s Motion on March&amp;#xA0;12
 2013; thus
 discovery is
 stayed until the Court rules on the Company&amp;#x2019;s Motion to
 Dismiss
 which was filed on September&amp;#xA0;24
 2012. On
 May&amp;#xA0;24
 2013
 the Judge in the matter issued a Report and
 Recommendation stating that the Motion to Dismiss be granted as to
 Plaintiff&amp;#x2019;s claim for unjust enrichment and denied in all
 other respects. The Company filed its Objections to the Report and
 Recommendation on June&amp;#xA0;7
 2013. The Court issued an Order
 adopting the Magistrate Judge&amp;#x2019;s Report and Recommendation on
 June&amp;#xA0;25
 2013. The Court denied the Company&amp;#x2019;s Motion for
 Reconsideration on July&amp;#xA0;8
 2013. The Company filed its Answer
 on August&amp;#xA0;2
 2013. The Company cannot at this time reasonably
 estimate a range of exposure
 if any
 of the potential
 liability.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 On August&amp;#xA0;16
 2013
 the &lt;i&gt;Langone&lt;/i&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Ruff&lt;/i&gt;
 &lt;i&gt;Funke&lt;/i&gt; and &lt;i&gt;Mazur&lt;/i&gt; cases were consolidated.&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 On June&amp;#xA0;22
 2012
 a putative class action complaint was filed
 against the Company in Los Angeles Superior Court (&lt;i&gt;Webster v.
 Del Monte&lt;/i&gt;) alleging false advertising under California&amp;#x2019;s
 consumer protection laws
 negligence
 breach of warranty and strict
 liability. Specifically
 the complaint alleges that the Company
 engaged in false advertising by representing that the Chicken Jerky
 Treats are healthy
 wholesome
 and safe for consumption by dogs
 and alleges that Plaintiff&amp;#x2019;s pet became ill after consuming
 Chicken Jerky Treats. The allegations apply to all other putative
 class members similarly situated. The complaint seeks certification
 as a class action and unspecified damages
 disgorgement of profits
 punitive damages
 attorneys&amp;#x2019; fees and injunctive relief. The
 Company denies these allegations and intends to vigorously defend
 itself. On September&amp;#xA0;6
 2012
 the Company filed a Notice of
 Removal to remove the case to the U.S. District Court for the
 Central District of California. Plaintiff subsequently filed a
 motion to amend its complaint to remove the federal class action
 claims and remand the case back to Los Angeles County Superior
 Court. The Company subsequently stipulated to Plaintiff&amp;#x2019;s
 motion
 and the case has been remanded to Los Angeles County
 Superior Court. The Company filed a Motion for Judgment on the
 Pleadings on July&amp;#xA0;3
 2013. The Plaintiff filed an Opposition
 on August&amp;#xA0;21
 2013. The Company filed its Reply on
 August&amp;#xA0;27
 2013. The Court denied the Company&amp;#x2019;s Motion
 for Judgment on the Pleadings on February&amp;#xA0;20
 2014. The
 Company cannot at this time reasonably estimate a range of
 exposure
 if any
 of the potential liability.&lt;/p&gt;


 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;

 other&amp;#xA0;current&amp;#xA0;assets&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;td valign=middle&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;td valign=middle align=right&gt;9.4&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=middle nowrap=nowrap&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=middle&gt;&lt;sup style=FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: top&gt;(1)&lt;/sup&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top&gt;Accounts&amp;#xA0;payable and accrued expenses&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=middle&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;

 &lt;tr&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top width=17% align=left&gt;&lt;sup style=FONT-SIZE: 85%; VERTICAL-ALIGN: top&gt;(1)&lt;/sup&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top align=left&gt;Includes $7.6 million of commodity
 contracts (asset derivatives) designated as cash flow hedges.&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;/tr&gt;
 &lt;/table&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0px; FONT-SIZE: 1px; MARGIN-TOP: 16px&gt;
 &amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 14pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Trade Promotions:&lt;/b&gt; Accruals for trade promotions are recorded
 primarily at the time a product is sold to the customer based on
 expected levels of performance. Settlement of these liabilities
 typically occurs in subsequent periods through an off-invoice
 allowance at the time of sale or through an authorized process for
 deductions taken by a customer from amounts otherwise due to the
 Company. Deductions are offset against related trade promotion
 accruals. The original estimated costs of trade promotions are
 reasonably likely to change in the future. Evaluations of the trade
 promotion liability are performed monthly and adjustments are made
 where appropriate to reflect changes in the Company&amp;#x2019;s
 estimates. Trade spending is recorded as a reduction to gross
 sales.&lt;/p&gt;

  

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 14pt&gt;

 &lt;p style=margin-top:14pt; margin-bottom:0pt; font-size:10pt; font-family:Times New Roman&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Retained-Insurance Liabilities:&lt;/b&gt; The Company accrues for
 retained-insurance risks associated with the deductible portion of
 any potential liabilities that might arise out of claims of
 employees
 customers or other third parties for personal injury or
 property damage occurring in the course of the Company&amp;#x2019;s
 operations. A third-party actuary is engaged to assist the Company
 in estimating the ultimate costs associated with certain retained
 insurance risks. Additionally
 the Company&amp;#x2019;s estimate of
 retained-insurance liabilities is subject to change as new events
 or circumstances develop which might materially impact the ultimate
 cost to settle these losses.&lt;/p&gt;

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 16pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Defined Contribution Plans.&lt;/b&gt; The Company participates in
 three defined contribution plans
 two of which have Company
 contributions. Company contributions to these defined contribution
 plans are based on employee contributions and compensation. Company
 contributions under these plans were as follows for the periods
 indicated (in millions):&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 16pt; MARGIN-TOP: 0pt&gt;

 Machinery and equipment&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom align=center&gt;10-20 years&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;/tr&gt;
 &lt;tr style=FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman&gt;
 &lt;td valign=top&gt;
 &lt;p style=FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-LEFT: 1em; TEXT-INDENT: -1em&gt;
 Computers and software&lt;/p&gt;
 &lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom&gt;&lt;font style=FONT-SIZE: 8pt&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;td valign=bottom align=center&gt;3-7 years&lt;/td&gt;
 &lt;/tr&gt;
 &lt;/table&gt;


 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 14pt&gt;
 &lt;b&gt;Coupon Redemption:&lt;/b&gt; Coupon redemption costs are accrued in
 the period in which the coupons are offered based on estimates of
 redemption rates that are developed by management.
 Management&amp;#x2019;s estimates are based on recommendations from
 independent coupon redemption clearing-houses
 as well as
 historical information. Should actual redemption rates vary from
 amounts estimated
 adjustments to accruals may be required. Coupon
 redemption costs are recorded as a reduction to gross sales.&lt;/p&gt;

  

 &lt;p style=MARGIN-BOTTOM: 0pt; FONT-SIZE: 10pt; FONT-FAMILY: Times New Roman; MARGIN-TOP: 14pt&gt;
 The table below shows the percentage of list sales for the leading
 customer
 as well as the top ten customers for the periods
 indicated:&lt;/p&gt;

 &lt;p style=BORDER-TOP: #000000 3px double&gt;&amp;#xA0;&lt;/p&gt;

 where upon the occurrence of an event or transaction pursuant to which the Sponsors realize a cash return on their interests in the Parent greater than a predetermined threshold

 or projects a credit balance deficit within seven years. A plan is in the Green Zone (Healthy) if it has a current funded percentage greater than 80% and does not have a projected credit balance deficit within seven years. The zone status is based on the plan's year end
 not the Company's year-end. The zone status is based on information that the Company received from the plan and is certified by the plan's actuary. During calendar year 2013
 the Bakery and Confectionery Union and Industry International Health Benefits and Pension Fund (Bakery and Confectionery Union Fund) was in Red Zone status. Although the current funding status as of calendar year 2013 was 66.41%

    
    

 2012

 consisting of acquisition-date fair value of assets transferred by the acquirer

 including
 but not limited to
 differences arising upon settlement.
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 this element represents an estimate of the high-end of the potential range (undiscounted) of the consideration which may be paid.
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            
                
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            
                
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 after deducting returns
 allowances and discounts.

Related Party
 Transactions





 Substantially all of Parent&#x2019;s outstanding common stock is
 held by Blue Holdings I
 L.P.; a partnership that is controlled by
 funds affiliated with the Sponsors. Blue Holdings GP
 LLC is the
 general partner of Blue Holdings I
 L.P. Funds affiliated with the
 Sponsors control Blue Holdings GP
 LLC. The following provides a
 summary of material transactions that involve the Company
 management
 the Sponsors and entities affiliated with the Sponsors
 Blue Sub
 Parent
 Blue Holdings I
 L.P. and Blue Holdings GP
 LLC.

 &#xA0;

 

 

 On March&#xA0;8
 2011
 in connection with the Merger
 entities
 affiliated with the Sponsors and an entity affiliated with
 AlpInvest Partners (the &#x201C;AlpInvest Manager
&#x201D; together
 with the affiliates of the Sponsors
 collectively
 the
 &#x201C;Managers&#x201D;) entered into a monitoring agreement (the
 &#x201C;Monitoring Agreement&#x201D;) with the Company
 Parent and
 Blue Holdings I
 L.P.
 pursuant to which the Managers provide
 management
 consulting
 financial and other advisory services to
 the Company and to its divisions
 subsidiaries
 parent entities and
 controlled affiliates. Pursuant to the Monitoring Agreement
 the
 Managers
 other than the AlpInvest Manager
 are entitled to receive
 an aggregate annual advisory fee to be allocated among the Sponsors
 in accordance with their respective equity holdings in Blue
 Holdings I
 L.P. in an amount equal to the greater of (i)&#xA0;$6.5
 million and (ii)&#xA0;1.00% of the Company&#x2019;s &#x201C;Adjusted
 EBITDA&#x201D; (as defined in the Senior Notes Indenture) less an
 annual advisory fee of approximately $0.25 million paid to the
 AlpInvest Manager. For fiscal 2014
 fiscal 2013
 and fiscal 2012
 the total expense for the Monitoring Agreement was $6.6 million
 $6.7 million
 and $6.5 million
 respectively. As of April&#xA0;27
 2014
 there was a payable of $1.6 million due to the Managers
 related to the Monitoring Agreement
 which amount is included in
 accounts payable and accrued expenses on the Consolidated Balance
 Sheets.

 The Managers also receive reimbursement of reasonable out-of-pocket
 expenses incurred in connection with the provision of services
 pursuant to the Monitoring Agreement. The Monitoring Agreement will
 continue indefinitely unless terminated by the consent of all the
 parties thereto. In addition
 the Monitoring Agreement will
 terminate automatically upon an initial public offering of Parent
 unless the Company elects by prior written notice to continue the
 Monitoring Agreement. Upon a change of control of Parent
 the
 Company may terminate the Monitoring Agreement.

 

 In February 2014
 following the sale of the Consumer Products
 Business
 the Company paid a total of $15.0 million to the Sponsors
 for transaction related fees
 which included $8.9 million to KKR
 $4.2 million to Vestar
 $1.6 million to Centerview
 and $0.3
 million to the AlpInvest Manager. The Company also paid an advisory
 fee of $9.4 million to Centerview Partners LLC
 an affiliate of
 Centerview.

 

 On July&#xA0;31
 2012
 the Company assigned its Right Of First
 Refusal (&#x201C;ROFR&#x201D;) with respect to its leased
 administrative space in Pittsburgh
 Pennsylvania (&#x201C;Pittsburgh
 Office Space&#x201D;) and the related Landlord Partnership Interests
 to an affiliate of KKR.&#xA0;On November&#xA0;20
 2012
 a KKR
 affiliate purchased 89% of the Landlord Partnership Interests
 and
 made a payment of $0.4 million to the Company in consideration of
 the prior assignment of the ROFR. As a result
 the KKR affiliate is
 the beneficiary of future lease payments made by the Company
 through the remaining term of the lease. For the fiscal year ended
 April&#xA0;27
 2014
 the Company paid approximately $2.8 million of
 rent to the KKR affiliate. For the period from November&#xA0;20
 2012 to April&#xA0;28
 2013
 the Company paid approximately $1.2
 million of rent to the KKR affiliate.

 

 The Company paid $3.5 million to a Vestar advisor for a
 finder&#x2019;s fee related to the Natural Balance acquisition
 during fiscal 2014.

 

 In February 2014
 the Company paid $0.4 million to KKR Capital
 Markets LLC
 an affiliate of KKR (&#x201C;KCM&#x201D;)
 for
 arrangement services in connection with entering into an amendment
 to the Senior Secured Term Loan Credit Agreement and refinancing
 the Senior Secured Asset-Based Revolving Credit Agreement.

 

 

 The Company made total purchases of $82.8 million from equity
 method investees during fiscal 2014.

 &#xA0;

 In January 2013
 the Company engaged KCM to act as a joint lead
 arranger and joint bookrunner in connection with the amendment to
 the Senior Secured Term Loan Credit Agreement.&#xA0;KCM received
 approximately $0.6 million for its services in arranging the
 transaction.

 if revenues from transactions with a single external customer amount to 10 percent or more of entity revenues
 including the disclosure of that fact
 the total amount of revenues from each such customer
 and the identity of the reportable segment or segments reporting the revenues. The entity need not disclose the identity of a major customer or the amount of revenues that each segment reports from that customer. For these purposes
 a group of companies known to the entity to be under common control is considered a single customer
 and the federal government
 a state government
 a local government such as a county or municipality
 or a foreign government is each considered a single customer.

 The following table presents information regarding the
 multi-employer plan of the Company:

 &#xA0;

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


 
 
 
 

 
 Zone&#xA0;Status
 
 
 Pending/
 
 
 
 
 

 months ended December&#xA0;31)
 
 
 
 Imposed
 

 


 Agreement


 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 



 





 Bakery and Confectionery

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Union and Industry

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 International Health

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Benefits and Pension Fund

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 



 &#xA0;

 &#xA0;

 &#xA0;

 
 

 ranks the funded status of multiemployer pension plans depending
 upon a plan&#x2019;s current and projected funding. A plan is in the
 Red Zone (Critical) if it has a current funded percentage less than
 65%. A plan is in the Yellow Zone (Endangered) if it has a current
 funded percentage of less than 80%
 or projects a credit balance
 deficit within seven years. A plan is in the Green Zone (Healthy)
 if it has a current funded percentage greater than 80% and does not
 have a projected credit balance deficit within seven years. The
 zone status is based on the plan&#x2019;s year end
 not the
 Company&#x2019;s year-end. The zone status is based on information
 that the Company received from the plan and is certified by the
 plan&#x2019;s actuary. During calendar year 2013
 the Bakery and
 Confectionery Union and Industry International Health Benefits and
 Pension Fund (Bakery and Confectionery Union Fund) was in Red Zone
 status. Although the current funding status as of calendar year
 2013 was 66.41%
 the Company&#x2019;s actuary concluded that the
 funding status is more than likely to fall below 65% within the
 next five years and has classified the Bakery and Confectionery




 &#xA0;

 
 

 Rehabilitation Plan as defined under ERISA has been implemented or




 &#xA0;

 
 

 to the Plan in the most current year due to funding shortfalls and




 &#xA0;

 
 

 Plan&#x2019;s Form 5500 as providing more than 5% of the total
 contributions for the plan year ending December&#xA0;31
 2012
 the

Other (income) expense
 net
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        


        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        



          

        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        


        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        


        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        
        

      
        

      



              









        
          

        
          
            
                
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 after income or loss from equity method investments
 but before income taxes
 extraordinary items
 and noncontrolling interest.
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            
                
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            
                
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 the components of which are not separately disclosed on the income statement
 resulting from ancillary business-related activities (that is
 excluding major activities considered part of the normal operations of the business) also known as other nonoperating income (expense) recognized for the period. Such amounts may include: (a) dividends
 (b) interest on securities
 (c) net gains or losses on securities
 (d) unusual costs
 (e) gains or losses on foreign exchange transactions
 and (f) miscellaneous other income and expense items.

 excluding financial assets and goodwill
 lacking physical substance with a finite life.
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 in 'PnYnMnDTnHnMnS' format
 for example
 'P1Y5M13D' represents the reported fact of one year
 five months
 and thirteen days.

 physical assets not used in production
 and which are not intended for resale
 to allocate or recognize the cost of such assets over their useful lives; or to record the reduction in book value of an intangible asset over the benefit period of such asset; or to reflect consumption during the period of an asset that is not used in production.
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    





















    
  
      

          

        

      






        
        


        
        

 
 
Business and Basis of
 Presentation



 On March&#xA0;8
 2011
 Del Monte Foods Company (&#x201C;DMFC&#x201D;)
 was acquired by an investor group led by funds affiliated with
 Kohlberg Kravis Roberts&#xA0;&amp; Co. L.P. (&#x201C;KKR&#x201D;)
 Vestar Capital Partners (&#x201C;Vestar&#x201D;) and Centerview
 Capital
 L.P. (&#x201C;Centerview
&#x201D;) and together with KKR and
 Vestar
 the &#x201C;Sponsors&#x201D;). The acquisition (also referred
 to as the &#x201C;Merger&#x201D;) was effected by the merger of Blue
 Merger Sub Inc. (&#x201C;Blue Sub&#x201D;) with and into DMFC
 with
 DMFC being the surviving corporation. As a result of the Merger
 DMFC became a wholly-owned subsidiary of Blue Acquisition Group
 Inc. (&#x201C;Parent&#x201D;). Del Monte Corporation
 (&#x201C;DMC
&#x201D; together with its consolidated subsidiaries
 &#x201C;Del Monte&#x201D;) was a direct
 wholly-owned subsidiary of
 DMFC. On April&#xA0;26
 2011
 DMFC merged with and into DMC
 with
 DMC being the surviving corporation. In connection with the sale of
 the Consumer Products Business (see &#x201C;Discontinued Operations
 and Assets Held for Sale&#x201D; below) on February&#xA0;18
 2014
 DMC changed its name to Big Heart Pet Brands (together with its
 consolidated subsidiaries
 &#x201C;Big Heart Pet&#x201D; or the
 &#x201C;Company&#x201D;).

 The Company operates on a 52 or 53-week fiscal year ending on the
 Sunday closest to April&#xA0;30. The results of operations for
 fiscal 2014
 fiscal 2013
 and fiscal 2012 each contain 52
 weeks.

 Big Heart Pet Brands is the largest U.S. standalone producer
 distributor and marketer of premium quality
 branded pet food and
 pet snacks. The Company&#x2019;s pet food and pet snacks brands

 Milk-Bone
 Kibbles &#x2018;n Bits

 Natural Balance
 Pup-Peroni
 Gravy Train
 Nature&#x2019;s
 Recipe
 Canine Carry Outs
 Milo&#x2019;s Kitchen
 names. The Company has one operating segment: Pet Products
 which
 manufactures markets and sells branded and private label dry and
 wet pet food and pet snacks. The former Consumer Products segment
 is now reported as discontinued operations. The Consumer Products
 segment manufactured
 marketed and sold branded and private label
 shelf-stable products
 including fruit
 vegetable
 tomato and broth
 products with food brands that included 

 College Inn
 S&amp;W
 &#x201C;Discontinued Operations and Assets Held for Sale&#x201D;
 below for details on the divestiture.

 As described in Note 5
 on July&#xA0;15
 2013
 the Company
 completed the acquisition of Natural Balance Pet Foods
 Inc.
 (&#x201C;Natural Balance&#x201D;)
 by obtaining 100% of the voting
 interest of Natural Balance. Natural Balance is a maker of premium
 pet products for dogs and cats sold throughout North America.

 On July&#xA0;11
 2013
 the Company purchased a minority equity
 interest in a co-packer for $14.6 million. The investment is
 accounted for under the equity method and is stated at cost plus
 the Company&#x2019;s share of undistributed earnings.

 On September&#xA0;16
 2013
 DMC formed a joint venture with a
 supplier. Investments through April&#xA0;27
 2014 totaled $3.9
 million. The investment is accounted for under the equity method
 and is stated at cost plus the Company&#x2019;s share of
 undistributed earnings.

 

 On October&#xA0;9
 2013
 DMC entered into a Purchase Agreement (the
 &#x201C;Purchase Agreement&#x201D;) with Del Monte Pacific Limited
 (&#x201C;DMPL&#x201D;) and its subsidiary
 Del Monte Foods Consumer
 Products
 Inc. (now known as Del Monte Foods
 Inc.)
 (the
 &#x201C;Acquiror&#x201D;). Pursuant to the terms of the Purchase
 Agreement
 the Company sold to the Acquiror the interests of
 certain subsidiaries related to the Company&#x2019;s Consumer
 Products business (the &#x201C;Consumer Products Business&#x201D;)
 and generally all assets primarily related to the Consumer Products
 Business (the &#x201C;Transferred Assets&#x201D;) for a purchase
 price of $1
675.0 million
 subject to a post-closing working
 capital adjustment. The Acquiror assumed the related liabilities
 (other than certain specified excluded liabilities). The
 transaction closed on February&#xA0;18
 2014 and the Company
 received gross proceeds equal to the purchase price plus an
 incremental preliminary working capital adjustment of approximately
 $110 million
 subject to a true-up in accordance with the terms of
 the Purchase Agreement. See Note 7 for use of the after tax net
 proceeds in connection with the sale. From closing
 the Company
 will have continuing involvement with the Acquiror under the terms
 of a transition services agreement and expects to have continuing
 cash flows with the discontinued operation for at least 12 months
 after the transaction close date. Management assessed the nature of
 its continuing involvement
 which includes providing continued
 information technology
 accounting and administrative service
 functions during the term of the agreement
 and continuing cash
 flows and determined them to not be significant.

 Accordingly
 the results of the Consumer Products Business have
 been reported as discontinued operations for all periods presented.
 Expenses allocated to discontinued operations are limited to
 selling
 administrative and distribution expenses that were
 directly attributable to the Consumer Products Business.
 Consequently
 certain expenses that have historically been
 allocated to the Consumer Products Business are not included in
 discontinued operations. The Company has combined cash flows from
 discontinued operations with cash flows from continuing operations
 within the operating
 investing and financing categories in the
 Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows for all periods
 presented.

 Any net proceeds not committed for reinvestment within 12 months of
 the transaction closing date were required to be used to repay
 debt. As such
 interest expense has not been allocated to
 discontinued operations.

 Unless otherwise noted
 all subsequent footnote disclosures
 represent continuing operations with the exception of Note 4
 which
 details the assets and liabilities of discontinued operations for
 the periods presented
 as well as the results of operations for
 discontinued operations.
 




        
          

        
          
            

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 consolidation and basis of presentation of financial statements disclosure.
              
                
              

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    





















    
  
      

Goodwill and Intangible Assets - Additional Information 1 (Detail) (Trademarks
 USD $)
 unless otherwise specified

        

      







          

        


        
        


        
        




        
          

        
          
            

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 excluding financial assets and goodwill
 lacking physical substance and having a projected indefinite period of benefit.

Other (Income) Expense
 net



 The components of other (income) expense
 net are as follows (in
 millions):

 &#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;2012&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;&#xA0;

Quarterly Results of Operations
 (unaudited)





 &#xA0;
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 


 
 
 
 
(in
 millions)
 

 



 Fiscal 2014:

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Net sales

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Operating income

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Net income (loss)

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 &#xA0;
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 


 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 
 
 
 

 
 


 
 
 
 
(in
 millions)
 

 



 Fiscal 2013:

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Net sales

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Operating income

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 




 Net income

 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 

 As described in Note 4
 the Company recognized a non-cash
 impairment charge of $193.8 million before income taxes in the
 second quarter of fiscal 2014 as well as a pre-tax gain on sale of
 $1.2 million (recognized in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2014)
 related to the sale of the Consumer Products Business. In the
 fourth quarter of fiscal 2014
 the Company also incurred a
 significant tax expense within discontinued operations associated
 with the significant taxable gain on the sale of the Consumer
 Products Business.

 Net sales and operating income as presented in the quarterly
 results of operations above are for continuing operations.
 




        
          

        
          
            

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    

                  
                    
                    








        
          

        
          
            

 including revenues
 gross profit
 income or loss before extraordinary items and earnings per share data. It also includes an indication if the information in the note is unaudited
 comments on the aggregate effect of year-end adjustments
 and an explanation of matters or transactions that affect comparability or are pertinent to an understanding of the information furnished.

A multiemployer plan is a pension or postretirement benefit plan to which two or more unrelated employers contribute where assets contributed by one participating employer may be used to provide benefits to employees of other participating employers.
